<ce:caption>

</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  ORTEP view of the [Ru(DMSO)(pz)Cl4]- anion in crystal 2. Ellipsoids are shown at 40% probability level and the H atoms are of arbitrary size.

<ce:simple-para view="all">ORTEP view of [Na][Ru(DMSO)(pz)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>DMSO (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) showing the labelling scheme of the asymmetric unit. Ellipsoids are shown at 40% probability level and the H atoms are of arbitrary size.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:figure id="fig3">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">ORTEP view of a ribbon in compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> showing the octahedral environment around the Na atom (-<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>-<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>-), which bridges the anions [Ru(DMSO)(pz)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  ORTEP view of a ribbon in compound 3 showing the octahedral environment around the Na atom (---), which bridges the anions [Ru(DMSO)(pz)Cl4]-.

<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Several new Ru(III) compounds containing both DMSO and a heterocyclic dinitrogen ligand were synthesized. The crystal structures of the <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-[Ru(DMSO)(pz)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (pz<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>pyrazine) monoanion, an analogue to the anticancer complex NAMI, with two different cations, tetraphenylphosphonium and Na show very different architectures. The Na complex has an interesting extended structure, while the PPh<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> complex shows discrete ions.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Several new Ru(III) compounds containing both DMSO and a heterocyclic dinitrogen ligand were synthesized. The crystal structures of the trans-[Ru(DMSO)(pz)Cl4]- (pz=pyrazine) monoanion, an analogue to the anticancer complex NAMI, with two different cations, tetraphenylphosphonium and Na show very different architectures. The Na complex has an interesting extended structure, while the PPh4 complex shows discrete ions.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Several new Ru(III) DMSO compounds including [PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4], [PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)(pyrazine)Cl4] (2), [PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)(4,4'-bipyridine)Cl4] and [PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)(pyrimidine)Cl4] were reported and characterized. The crystal structure of 2 and its Na+ analogue were determined by X-ray diffraction methods. The     PPh   4     +     complex 2 is a discrete ionic compound, while the compound [Na]trans-[Ru(DMSO)(pyrazine)Cl4]⋅DMSO (3) crystallized with a molecule of DMSO. The environment around the Na atom is a distorted octahedron with short contacts with three chloro ligands, two O atoms from the bonded and unbonded DMSO molecules, and the unbonded N atom of the pyrazine ligand. The Na atoms form bridges between the complexed anions in 3 resulting in the formation of infinite chains or ribbons parallel to the b axis. The chains are held together by van der Waals interactions.

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The anticancer drug <ce:italic>cisplatin</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-Pt(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and a few other platinum agents are widely used in the clinical treatment of testicular, ovarian, bladder, head and neck tumors . The clinical success of <ce:italic>cisplatin</ce:italic> has proved to be limited due to significant side effects and resistance that cause relapse . Therefore, much interest has focused on developing new chemotherapeutic metal complexes with improved properties. Subsequent studies on many platinum-containing complexes have been performed . However, most of these complexes have been proven to have the same or only slightly better efficacy than <ce:italic>cisplatin</ce:italic>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The anticancer drug cisplatin, cis-Pt(NH3)2Cl2, and a few other platinum agents are widely used in the clinical treatment of testicular, ovarian, bladder, head and neck tumors . The clinical success of cisplatin has proved to be limited due to significant side effects and resistance that cause relapse . Therefore, much interest has focused on developing new chemotherapeutic metal complexes with improved properties. Subsequent studies on many platinum-containing complexes have been performed . However, most of these complexes have been proven to have the same or only slightly better efficacy than cisplatin .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">For the past two decades, much work has focused on the synthesis and pharmacological evaluation of new compounds containing ruthenium centers . A major reason for this can be attributed to the reduced side effects of these complexes, due to their lower systemic toxicity. Complexes with ruthenium(III) centers have been synthesized and have demonstrated antitumor activity, as well as remarkable antimetastatic behavior . It is speculated that ruthenium(III) complexes are reduced <ce:italic>in vivo</ce:italic> to the more labile ruthenium(II) and this is a major reason for its biological activity . Due to lower oxygen and lower pH at tumor sites, ruthenium’s “activation by reduction” process makes it very selective as the metal complex may accumulate in these hypoxic environments . Only a small number of ruthenium(III) complexes have been found to be effective, with the best examples being: [Na]<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-[RuCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(DMSO)(Im)] , NAMI, its imidazolium analogue [ImH]<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-RuCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(DMSO)(Im)] , NAMI-A and the indazole compound [IndH]<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-[RuCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(Ind)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] , KP1019. NAMI-A shows high selectivity for solid tumor metastases  and low toxicity at pharmacologically active doses and was found to effectively interfere with cell cycle regulation and angiogenesis . The above properties have made NAMI-A the first ruthenium(III) compound to successfully complete phase I clinical trials . The main feature of the majority of these complexes is the presence of four chlorides, one DMSO, and one N-donor ligand in the coordination sphere. At present, very few examples of such ruthenium(III) complexes exist that have been structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction methods. These include complexes, for example, where the N-donor ligand is ammonia , thiazole , guaninium , imidazole , pyridine , triazole  as well as symmetrical ruthenium dimers with pyrazine, pyrimidine, and bipyridine , and the unsymmetrical dimer with bridging pyrazine . Here we report the synthesis and characterization of several ruthenium(III) complexes with dimethylsulfoxide and heterocyclic dinitrogen ligands as well as the crystal structures of the [Ru(DMSO)(pz)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (pz<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>pyrazine) monoanion with two different cations, tetraphenylphosphonium (PPh<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>) and Na. These cations are quite different and the architectures of the crystal structures were expected to differ considerably. These two compounds are the first two Ru(III) species containing a terminal pyrazine ligand to be characterized structurally.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: For the past two decades, much work has focused on the synthesis and pharmacological evaluation of new compounds containing ruthenium centers . A major reason for this can be attributed to the reduced side effects of these complexes, due to their lower systemic toxicity. Complexes with ruthenium(III) centers have been synthesized and have demonstrated antitumor activity, as well as remarkable antimetastatic behavior . It is speculated that ruthenium(III) complexes are reduced in vivo to the more labile ruthenium(II) and this is a major reason for its biological activity . Due to lower oxygen and lower pH at tumor sites, ruthenium's "activation by reduction" process makes it very selective as the metal complex may accumulate in these hypoxic environments . Only a small number of ruthenium(III) complexes have been found to be effective, with the best examples being: [Na]trans-[RuCl4(DMSO)(Im)] , NAMI, its imidazolium analogue [ImH]trans-RuCl4(DMSO)(Im)] , NAMI-A and the indazole compound [IndH]trans-[RuCl4(Ind)2] , KP1019. NAMI-A shows high selectivity for solid tumor metastases  and low toxicity at pharmacologically active doses and was found to effectively interfere with cell cycle regulation and angiogenesis . The above properties have made NAMI-A the first ruthenium(III) compound to successfully complete phase I clinical trials . The main feature of the majority of these complexes is the presence of four chlorides, one DMSO, and one N-donor ligand in the coordination sphere. At present, very few examples of such ruthenium(III) complexes exist that have been structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction methods. These include complexes, for example, where the N-donor ligand is ammonia , thiazole , guaninium , imidazole , pyridine , triazole  as well as symmetrical ruthenium dimers with pyrazine, pyrimidine, and bipyridine , and the unsymmetrical dimer with bridging pyrazine . Here we report the synthesis and characterization of several ruthenium(III) complexes with dimethylsulfoxide and heterocyclic dinitrogen ligands as well as the crystal structures of the [Ru(DMSO)(pz)Cl4]- (pz=pyrazine) monoanion with two different cations, tetraphenylphosphonium (PPh4) and Na. These cations are quite different and the architectures of the crystal structures were expected to differ considerably. These two compounds are the first two Ru(III) species containing a terminal pyrazine ligand to be characterized structurally.

<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Ethanol (100%) was purchased from Pharmaco Products Inc. All other reagents and solvents were purchased from Sigma Aldrich Inc. IR spectra were recorded in the solid state on a Nicolet 4700 FTIR spectrometer between 4000 and 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra were measured in D<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, acetone-<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, CDCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, and CD<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN on a Varian Gemini 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MHz spectrometer. The solvent peaks at 4.80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, 2.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, 7.26<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, and 1.94<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm for D<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, CD<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COCD<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CDCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, and CD<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN, respectively, were used as internal standards for the <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra. Spectral abbreviations used below: br (broad), vbr (very broad), s (strong), m (medium), w (weak), sh (shoulder).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Ethanol (100%) was purchased from Pharmaco Products Inc. All other reagents and solvents were purchased from Sigma Aldrich Inc. IR spectra were recorded in the solid state on a Nicolet 4700 FTIR spectrometer between 4000 and 250cm-1. 1H NMR spectra were measured in D2O, acetone-d 6, CDCl3, and CD3CN on a Varian Gemini 300MHz spectrometer. The solvent peaks at 4.80ppm, 2.05ppm, 7.26ppm, and 1.94ppm for D2O, CD3COCD3, CDCl3, and CD3CN, respectively, were used as internal standards for the 1H NMR spectra. Spectral abbreviations used below: br (broad), vbr (very broad), s (strong), m (medium), w (weak), sh (shoulder).

Synthesis

[(DMSO)2H]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4], [Na]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4], and [NBu4]trans-[RuCl4(DMSO)2] (Bu= n-butyl) were synthesized according to the literature methods .

 [PPh  4  ]trans-[Ru(DMSO)  2  Cl  4  ] (  1  ). Tetraphenylphosphonium chloride (0.34g, 0.92mmol) dissolved in 6mL of H2O was added to a solution of [(DMSO)2H]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4] (0.34g, 0.61mmol) dissolved in 3mL of H2O, while stirring. A yellow precipitate formed within minutes. The precipitate was collected by filtration, washed with diethylether and vacuum dried. Yield: 89%. IR (cm-1): 1107s ν(DMSO-S), 416w ν(Ru-S), 339, 319s ν(Ru-Cl). 1H NMR (CD3CN/ppm): -13.0 (DMSO-S), 7.95, 7.74 (phenyl protons).

elements.clean_text: [Na]trans-[Ru(DMSO)(pz)Cl  4  ] ⋅ DMSO (  3  ). The synthesis of this compound was similar to that reported  with some changes. Pyrazine (80.2mg, 1.00mmol) dissolved in 5mL of acetone was added to a solution of 82.5mg (0.198mmol) of [Na]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4] dissolved in 2mL of DMSO. The resulting mixture was filtered and the filtrate was stirred at room temperature for 1.5h. A 50/50 acetone/diethylether solution (5.0mL) was added to the reaction mixture followed by an additional 5.0mL of diethylether. The mixture was then placed at 4° C. Orange crystals appeared within 48h. The mother liquor was decanted and the crystals washed with diethylether. Yield: 67%. 1H NMR (D2O/ppm): -13.9 (br), (DMSO-S), -7.5 (vbr, H3,5 pyz), -2.1 (br, H2,6 pyz). This compound was reported, but the solvate molecules appear different .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Crystallographic measurements and structure resolution</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The crystallographic measurements of crystals <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were done on a Bruker P4 diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) radiation. The cell dimensions were determined at room temperature, from a least-squares refinement of the angles 2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>ω</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic> obtained for well-centered reflections. elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic measurements and structure resolution

The crystallographic measurements of crystals 2 and 3 were done on a Bruker P4 diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα (λ =0.71073Å) radiation. The cell dimensions were determined at room temperature, from a least-squares refinement of the angles 2θ, ω and χ obtained for well-centered reflections. The data collection was made by the 2θ/ω scan technique using the xscans program . The background time to scan time ratio was 0.5. The coordinates of the Pt atom were determined by direct methods and all the other non-hydrogen atoms were found by the usual Fourier methods. The refinement of the structure was done on F 2 by full matrix least-squares analysis. The hydrogen atom positions were fixed in their calculated positions with U eq =1.2 U eq (or 1.5 for methyl groups) of the carbon to which they are bonded. Corrections were made for absorption (semi-empirical from psi-scans for 2 and integration for 3), Lorentz and polarization effects. The calculations were done using the Bruker shelxtl system . The crystallographic data and details are shown in  .

</ce:display>The synthesis and characterization of this ionic complex has not been reported yet in the literature, therefore we give a brief description. The IR spectrum of the compound shows a <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(S–O) vibration at 1107<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Absorption at 416<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> was assigned to the metal stretching vibration <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(Ru–S) while those at 339 and 319<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> were attributed to <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(Ru–Cl). The NMR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and all of the complexes reported here show peaks that are characteristic of complexes containing paramagnetic ruthenium(III). Protons close to the paramagnetic center have large line-width (often some peaks are too wide to be observable) and are shifted greatly upfield . The peak at −13.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is assigned to the coordinated DMSO (through the S atom).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

[PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4] (1)

This yellow compound was synthesized from the aqueous reaction of [(DMSO)2H]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4] with tetraphenylphosphonium chloride.   [ ( DMSO   )   2   H ] trans - [ Ru ( DMSO   )   2     Cl   4   ] + [   PPh   4   ] Cl   →     H   2   O   [   PPh   4   ] trans - [ Ru ( DMSO   )   2     Cl   4   ]   The synthesis and characterization of this ionic complex has not been reported yet in the literature, therefore we give a brief description. The IR spectrum of the compound shows a ν(S-O) vibration at 1107cm-1. Absorption at 416cm-1 was assigned to the metal stretching vibration ν(Ru-S) while those at 339 and 319cm-1 were attributed to ν(Ru-Cl). The NMR spectrum of 1 and all of the complexes reported here show peaks that are characteristic of complexes containing paramagnetic ruthenium(III). Protons close to the paramagnetic center have large line-width (often some peaks are too wide to be observable) and are shifted greatly upfield . The peak at -13.0ppm is assigned to the coordinated DMSO (through the S atom).

[PPh4][Ru(DMSO)(pyrazine)Cl4] (2)

This new ionic complex was synthesized from the reaction of the bis-DMSO Ru(III) ionic complex 1 with pyrazine (pz) as shown in the following equation:   [   PPh   4   ] trans - [ Ru ( DMSO   )   2     Cl   4   ] + pz   →   acetone/acetonitrile   [   PPh   4   ] trans - [ Ru ( DMSO ) ( pz )   Cl   4   ]   Alternatively, compound 2 was also synthesized from the aqueous reaction of compound 3 with tetraphenylphosphonium chloride or tetraphenylphosphonium bromide.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The IR spectrum of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows a <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(S–O) vibration at 1108<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, a <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(Ru–S) band at 420<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(Ru–Cl) vibrations at 342 and 328<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The NMR spectrum shows a peak at −12.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm integrating to six protons assigned to the coordinated DMSO, while the peak at −1.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm integrating to two protons is assigned to the protons (H<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> and H<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>) on the pyrazine ring. The protons on the pyrazine ring (H<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> and H<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>) closest to the paramagnetic ruthenium center are seen in a very broad peak at −5.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm (for labeling see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The IR spectrum of 2 shows a ν(S-O) vibration at 1108cm-1, a ν(Ru-S) band at 420cm-1 and ν(Ru-Cl) vibrations at 342 and 328cm-1. The NMR spectrum shows a peak at -12.6ppm integrating to six protons assigned to the coordinated DMSO, while the peak at -1.6ppm integrating to two protons is assigned to the protons (H3 and H5) on the pyrazine ring. The protons on the pyrazine ring (H2 and H6) closest to the paramagnetic ruthenium center are seen in a very broad peak at -5.6ppm (for labeling see  ).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was recrystallized from acetone/diethylether and the crystals were studied by crystallographic methods. The results have shown that the orange crystals consist of discrete complexed anions, [Ru(DMSO)(pz)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>) and [PPh<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations. The complexed anion is the <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> isomer and the coordination around the Ru(III) center is octahedral. The bond distances and angles are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>. The <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic> angles around the metal vary between 87.73(7)° and 92.66(3)°, while the <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> angles are between 177.32(3)° and 179.07(7)°. The Ru–Cl bond distances range from 2.3425(9) to 2.3589(10)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, the Ru–S bond is 2.2941(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the Ru–N distance is 2.118(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. These values are in agreement with published values found in a few related structures .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 2 was recrystallized from acetone/diethylether and the crystals were studied by crystallographic methods. The results have shown that the orange crystals consist of discrete complexed anions, [Ru(DMSO)(pz)Cl4]- ( ) and [PPh4]+ cations. The complexed anion is the trans isomer and the coordination around the Ru(III) center is octahedral. The bond distances and angles are shown in  . The cis angles around the metal vary between 87.73(7)° and 92.66(3)°, while the trans angles are between 177.32(3)° and 179.07(7)°. The Ru-Cl bond distances range from 2.3425(9) to 2.3589(10)Å, the Ru-S bond is 2.2941(9)Å and the Ru-N distance is 2.118(2)Å. These values are in agreement with published values found in a few related structures .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The environment around the S atom in the DMSO ligand is approximately tetrahedral but there are small deformations. The O–S–C angles are larger (ave. 107.18(17)°) than the C–S–C angle (98.77(18)°) as expected. The Ru–S–O angle (117.98(10)°) is also larger than the Ru–S–C angles (ave. 111.95(13)°). The average angle Ru–N–C is 121.9(2)°. The N1–C bond lengths (ave. 1.332(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) are not different from those of N4–C (ave. 1.328(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), but the angles C–N–C are different. The internal ring angle at the metal-bonded N1 atom is larger (116.3(3)°) than the angle of the non-bonded N4 atom (114.7(3)°) as observed in Pt(II) compounds of the type <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>- and <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-Pt(R<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO)(pz)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> where the bonded angle C2–N1–C6 is slightly larger than the C3–N4–C5 angle .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The environment around the S atom in the DMSO ligand is approximately tetrahedral but there are small deformations. The O-S-C angles are larger (ave. 107.18(17)°) than the C-S-C angle (98.77(18)°) as expected. The Ru-S-O angle (117.98(10)°) is also larger than the Ru-S-C angles (ave. 111.95(13)°). The average angle Ru-N-C is 121.9(2)°. The N1-C bond lengths (ave. 1.332(4)Å) are not different from those of N4-C (ave. 1.328(5)Å), but the angles C-N-C are different. The internal ring angle at the metal-bonded N1 atom is larger (116.3(3)°) than the angle of the non-bonded N4 atom (114.7(3)°) as observed in Pt(II) compounds of the type cis- and trans-Pt(R2SO)(pz)Cl2 where the bonded angle C2-N1-C6 is slightly larger than the C3-N4-C5 angle .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In order to minimize the interactions with the rest of the molecule, the pyrazine ligand is at ≈45° to the different Ru square planes. Here, the dihedral angle between the pyrazine and the RuN1S1Cl1Cl3 plane is 47.65(11)°, while it is 42.36(10)° with the RuN1S1Cl2Cl4 plane. In the DMSO ligand, the O atom of DMSO was found almost in the RuS1N1Cl1Cl3 plane, which reduces steric hindrance in the complexed ion, since the larger methyl groups are far from the four <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic> chloro ligands. The torsion angles Cl1–Ru–S–O and Cl3–Ru–S–O are −7.14(15)° and 172.94(15)°, respectively. In this conformation of the DMSO and pyrazine ligands, the energy of the molecular ion is close to a minimum.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In order to minimize the interactions with the rest of the molecule, the pyrazine ligand is at ~45° to the different Ru square planes. Here, the dihedral angle between the pyrazine and the RuN1S1Cl1Cl3 plane is 47.65(11)°, while it is 42.36(10)° with the RuN1S1Cl2Cl4 plane. In the DMSO ligand, the O atom of DMSO was found almost in the RuS1N1Cl1Cl3 plane, which reduces steric hindrance in the complexed ion, since the larger methyl groups are far from the four cis chloro ligands. The torsion angles Cl1-Ru-S-O and Cl3-Ru-S-O are -7.14(15)° and 172.94(15)°, respectively. In this conformation of the DMSO and pyrazine ligands, the energy of the molecular ion is close to a minimum.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The PPh<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> cations are normal. The average P–C bond distance is 1.800(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å with an average C–P–C angle of 109.48(13)°. No H-bonds are expected in this crystal. The ions are held together in the crystal by electrostatic forces and by van der Waals interactions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The PPh4 cations are normal. The average P-C bond distance is 1.800(3)Å with an average C-P-C angle of 109.48(13)°. No H-bonds are expected in this crystal. The ions are held together in the crystal by electrostatic forces and by van der Waals interactions.

</ce:display>The orange compound was crystallized in a mixture of acetone and diethylether and the crystals were studied by X-ray diffraction methods. The results have shown that the compound crystallized with a molecule of solvent (DMSO). The reported compound , which was not studied by crystallographic methods, contained 1.5 molecule of DMSO and 0.5 molecule of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, although it was crystallized from the same solvents.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
[Na][Ru(DMSO)(pyrazine)Cl4]⋅DMSO (3)

This compound was synthesized from the reaction of [Na][Ru(DMSO)2Cl4] with pyrazine in acetone and DMSO similar to the procedure already reported.   [ Na ] [ Ru ( DMSO   )   2     Cl   4   ] + pz   →   DMSO   acetone   [ Na ] [ Ru ( DMSO ) ( pz )   Cl   4   ] ⋅ DMSO   The orange compound was crystallized in a mixture of acetone and diethylether and the crystals were studied by X-ray diffraction methods. The results have shown that the compound crystallized with a molecule of solvent (DMSO). The reported compound , which was not studied by crystallographic methods, contained 1.5 molecule of DMSO and 0.5 molecule of H2O, although it was crystallized from the same solvents.

<ce:para view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor> shows the labeling scheme of the asymmetric unit in crystal <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The complexed anion is the <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> isomer and the coordination around the Ru(III) center is octahedral. The bond distances and angles are shown in . The <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic> angles around the metal vary between 87.95(3)° and 93.96(3)°, while the <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> angles are between 176.43(2)° and 177.74(2)°. The Ru–Cl bond distances range from 2.3395(8) to 2.3754(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, the Ru–S bond is 2.3027(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the Ru–N distance is 2.1257(19)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. These values are very similar to those observed in crystal <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> described above and they are in agreement with published values found in a few related structures .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: shows the labeling scheme of the asymmetric unit in crystal 3. The complexed anion is the trans isomer and the coordination around the Ru(III) center is octahedral. The bond distances and angles are shown in . The cis angles around the metal vary between 87.95(3)° and 93.96(3)°, while the trans angles are between 176.43(2)° and 177.74(2)°. The Ru-Cl bond distances range from 2.3395(8) to 2.3754(7)Å, the Ru-S bond is 2.3027(7)Å and the Ru-N distance is 2.1257(19)Å. These values are very similar to those observed in crystal 2 described above and they are in agreement with published values found in a few related structures .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The environment around the bonded S atom in the DMSO ligand is approximately tetrahedral but there are small deformations. The O–S1–C angles are larger (ave. 106.39(17)°) than the C–S1–C angle (100.4(2)°) as expected. The Ru–S–O angle (117.73(8)°) is also larger than the Ru–S–C angles (ave. 112.15(17)°). The average angle Ru–N–C is 121.64(16)°. The N1–C bonds (ave. 1.343(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) are not very different from the N4–C bonds (ave. 1.333(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), but the angles C–N–C are slightly different. The internal ring angle at the metal-bonded N1 atom is slightly larger (116.7(2)°) than the angle of the non-bonded N4 atom (115.2(2)°), as observed in crystal <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, which also contains a monodentate pyrazine ligand.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The environment around the bonded S atom in the DMSO ligand is approximately tetrahedral but there are small deformations. The O-S1-C angles are larger (ave. 106.39(17)°) than the C-S1-C angle (100.4(2)°) as expected. The Ru-S-O angle (117.73(8)°) is also larger than the Ru-S-C angles (ave. 112.15(17)°). The average angle Ru-N-C is 121.64(16)°. The N1-C bonds (ave. 1.343(3)Å) are not very different from the N4-C bonds (ave. 1.333(3)Å), but the angles C-N-C are slightly different. The internal ring angle at the metal-bonded N1 atom is slightly larger (116.7(2)°) than the angle of the non-bonded N4 atom (115.2(2)°), as observed in crystal 2, which also contains a monodentate pyrazine ligand.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> crystallized with a molecule of DMSO which is not bonded to the Ru(III) atom. The S2–O2 bond is longer (1.496(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) than the S1–O1 bond distance in crystals <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (ave. 1.469(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) as expected when the S atom is not coordinated to a metal. When the binding site of DMSO is the S atom, the order of the S–O bond increases when compared to the free molecule, while it is reduced if the molecule is bonded to the metal atom through its O atom. The NMR and IR spectra are in agreement with the published data. Only one <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(S–O) band was observed at 1104<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Complex 3 crystallized with a molecule of DMSO which is not bonded to the Ru(III) atom. The S2-O2 bond is longer (1.496(2)Å) than the S1-O1 bond distance in crystals 2 and 3 (ave. 1.469(2)Å) as expected when the S atom is not coordinated to a metal. When the binding site of DMSO is the S atom, the order of the S-O bond increases when compared to the free molecule, while it is reduced if the molecule is bonded to the metal atom through its O atom. The NMR and IR spectra are in agreement with the published data. Only one ν(S-O) band was observed at 1104cm-1 .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The O atom of the bonded DMSO ligand was found close to the RuS1N1Cl2Cl4 plane, which reduces steric hindrance in the complexed anion, since the larger methyl groups are far for the four <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic> chloro ligands. The torsion angles Cl2–Ru–S1–O1 and Cl4–Ru–S1–O1 are −161.74(11)° and 21.71(11)°, respectively. The plane of pyrazine is located at about ≈45° from the two different Ru(III) square planes. The dihedral angle between the pyrazine and the RuN1S1Cl2Cl4 plane is 41.56(6)°, while it is 48.18(7)° with the RuN1S1Cl1Cl4 plane. This conformation of the molecular ion is similar to the one observed in crystal <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and corresponds approximately to the one of lowest energy.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The O atom of the bonded DMSO ligand was found close to the RuS1N1Cl2Cl4 plane, which reduces steric hindrance in the complexed anion, since the larger methyl groups are far for the four cis chloro ligands. The torsion angles Cl2-Ru-S1-O1 and Cl4-Ru-S1-O1 are -161.74(11)° and 21.71(11)°, respectively. The plane of pyrazine is located at about ~45° from the two different Ru(III) square planes. The dihedral angle between the pyrazine and the RuN1S1Cl2Cl4 plane is 41.56(6)°, while it is 48.18(7)° with the RuN1S1Cl1Cl4 plane. This conformation of the molecular ion is similar to the one observed in crystal 2 and corresponds approximately to the one of lowest energy.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The environment around the Na atoms was closely examined. There are six atoms in its close environment. The distances and angles are shown in . The geometry is a distorted octahedron. Three of the close contacts are shown in . The Na–O1 (from bonded DMSO) and Na–O2 (unbonded DMSO) distances are 2.303(2) and 2.324(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The Na–Cl4 distance is 2.9222(12) Å´. There are three other short contacts with the following: N4′ (2.519(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), Cl1′ (2.7760(13)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), and Cl4′ (2.8404(13)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The chloro ligand Cl4 forms a bridge between two Na atoms, while Cl1 forms a bridge between a Na and a Ru atom. The two other Cl ligands are not involved with the Na atoms. The DMSO ligand forms a bridge between a Ru (through its S atom) atom and a Na (through its O) atom, while the S atom of the second DMSO molecule is free, but its O atom is in the close environment of the Na atom. There are important distortions from the octahedral structure around the Na atom. The <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic> angles vary between 72.25(3)° (Cl′–Na–Cl4′) and 106.54(7)° (O2–Na–Cl4), while the <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> angles are between 154.51(7)° and 175.65(8)°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The environment around the Na atoms was closely examined. There are six atoms in its close environment. The distances and angles are shown in . The geometry is a distorted octahedron. Three of the close contacts are shown in . The Na-O1 (from bonded DMSO) and Na-O2 (unbonded DMSO) distances are 2.303(2) and 2.324(2)Å, respectively. The Na-Cl4 distance is 2.9222(12) Å´. There are three other short contacts with the following: N4' (2.519(2)Å), Cl1' (2.7760(13)Å), and Cl4' (2.8404(13)Å). The chloro ligand Cl4 forms a bridge between two Na atoms, while Cl1 forms a bridge between a Na and a Ru atom. The two other Cl ligands are not involved with the Na atoms. The DMSO ligand forms a bridge between a Ru (through its S atom) atom and a Na (through its O) atom, while the S atom of the second DMSO molecule is free, but its O atom is in the close environment of the Na atom. There are important distortions from the octahedral structure around the Na atom. The cis angles vary between 72.25(3)° (Cl'-Na-Cl4') and 106.54(7)° (O2-Na-Cl4), while the trans angles are between 154.51(7)° and 175.65(8)°.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The Na atom has a very important role in this structure. It bridges the different complexed ions to form infinite polymeric chains or ribbons parallel to the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis. One of these is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>. The two ligands Cl2 and Cl3, which are not involved with the Na atoms point towards the outside of the chain, along with S2 and the two C atoms of the free DMSO molecule. Several cycles are formed, ranging from four atoms (Ru, Cl1, Na, Cl4) to seven atoms (Ru, Cl1, Na, Cl4, Na, O1, S1). These neutral ribbons are held together by van der Waals forces. There may be weak π–π stacking interactions of the pyrazine ligands, as the distance between pyrazine pairs shown in  is 3.548(16)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The Na atom has a very important role in this structure. It bridges the different complexed ions to form infinite polymeric chains or ribbons parallel to the b axis. One of these is shown in  . The two ligands Cl2 and Cl3, which are not involved with the Na atoms point towards the outside of the chain, along with S2 and the two C atoms of the free DMSO molecule. Several cycles are formed, ranging from four atoms (Ru, Cl1, Na, Cl4) to seven atoms (Ru, Cl1, Na, Cl4, Na, O1, S1). These neutral ribbons are held together by van der Waals forces. There may be weak π-π stacking interactions of the pyrazine ligands, as the distance between pyrazine pairs shown in  is 3.548(16)Å .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">A few related structures were reported with the sodium cation. In [Na][Ru(DMSO)(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2DMSO and [Na][Ru(DMSO)(Im)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COCH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
, the environment around the Na atom is tetrahedral with four Na–O distances between 2.272(4) and 2.489(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. But the long-range arrangement in the crystal was not discussed. A few other related structures containing Na ions were published, but the environment around the Na atom was not considered . In these structures, the role of the Na ions in the architecture, besides its counterion function, was not studied.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A few related structures were reported with the sodium cation. In [Na][Ru(DMSO)(NH3)Cl4]⋅2DMSO and [Na][Ru(DMSO)(Im)Cl4]⋅H2O, CH3COCH3 , the environment around the Na atom is tetrahedral with four Na-O distances between 2.272(4) and 2.489(3)Å. But the long-range arrangement in the crystal was not discussed. A few other related structures containing Na ions were published, but the environment around the Na atom was not considered . In these structures, the role of the Na ions in the architecture, besides its counterion function, was not studied.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In crystal <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the unbonded DMSO molecule plays also a very important role in the formation of the chains. In a few reported structures containing the same cation, the chains are not formed, but rather shorter oligomers  containing two Ru(III) and two Na atoms were produced. For the latter structures, the tetrahedral environment around the Na atoms is formed with four O atoms from DMSO or H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In crystal 3, the unbonded DMSO molecule plays also a very important role in the formation of the chains. In a few reported structures containing the same cation, the chains are not formed, but rather shorter oligomers  containing two Ru(III) and two Na atoms were produced. For the latter structures, the tetrahedral environment around the Na atoms is formed with four O atoms from DMSO or H2O molecules.

elements.clean_text:
[NBu4]trans-[RuCl4(DMSO)(bpy)] (4) and [PPh4]trans-[RuCl4(DMSO)(bpy)] (5)

[PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)(bpy)Cl4] (5) (bpy=4,4'-bipyridine) was prepared from [PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4] in methylene chloride as shown in the following equation:   [   PPh   4   ] trans - [ Ru ( DMSO   )   2     Cl   4   ] + 4 ,   4   '   -bpy   →   methylene chloride   [   PPh   4   ] [ Ru ( DMSO ) ( bpy )   Cl   4   ]   The NMR spectrum of compound 5 showed, along with signals for the tetraphenyl phosphonium cation, several peaks for the protons of the coordinated ligands. The signal at -12.8ppm is assigned to the coordinated DMSO while the peak at -1.7ppm is assigned to the protons (H3 and H5) on the coordinated pyridine ring but furthest from the paramagnetic ruthenium(III) center. The protons closest to the ruthenium center (H2 and H6, ) are not observed due to a line-width that is too broad for the peak to be seen. The protons on the second pyridine ring are observed at 5.5 (    H     3   '       and     H     5   '      ) and 7.5ppm (    H     2   '       and     H     6   '      ) for the two pairs closer and further from the ruthenium atom, respectively. The IR spectrum of 5 shows a terminal bpy mode at 1595cm-1 along with a ν(S-O) vibration at 1107cm-1, a ν(Ru-S) band at 422cm-1, and a ν(Ru-Cl) vibration at 331cm-1.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">[NBu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-[Ru(DMSO)(bpy)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) was prepared similarly to complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, however the reaction was done in acetone solution. The NMR and IR spectral characterization and signal assignments were also similar, except in the proton NMR, where all four sets of bpy proton pairs were observed in this case. The protons closest to the ruthenium atom (H<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> and H<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>), unobservable for complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> are seen as a very broad peak at −6.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: [NBu4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)(bpy)Cl4] (4) was prepared similarly to complex 5, however the reaction was done in acetone solution. The NMR and IR spectral characterization and signal assignments were also similar, except in the proton NMR, where all four sets of bpy proton pairs were observed in this case. The protons closest to the ruthenium atom (H2 and H6), unobservable for complex 5 are seen as a very broad peak at -6.0ppm.

[PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)(pym)Cl4] (6)

[PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)(pym)Cl4] (6) was prepared from [PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4] in methylene chloride as shown in the following equation:   [   PPh   4   ] trans - [ Ru ( DMSO   )   2     Cl   4   ] + pyrimidine   →   methylene chloride   [   PPh   4   ] [ Ru ( DMSO ) ( pym )   Cl   4   ]   The NMR spectrum of compound 6 in acetonitrile solution showed, along with signals for the tetraphenylphosphonium cation, five peaks for the protons of the coordinated ligands. The signal at -13.0ppm is assigned to the coordinated DMSO as expected. There are four peaks seen for the pyrimidine ligand as each proton is unique in this case due to the loss of symmetry in the ligand once it has coordinated. The peak at 6.34ppm has the narrowest line-width and is therefore assigned to the proton furthest from the paramagnetic center, H4 . The peak at -0.58ppm is assigned to the H5 proton similar to complex 3. Two very broad peaks are observed at -1.7 and -6.5ppm and are assigned to H6 and H2, respectively, those closest to the paramagnetic ruthenium center. In chloroform solution the peaks were observed at 6.32, -0.52, and -12.7 for the H4, H5, and DMSO protons, respectively. The H2 and H6 protons were too broad to be seen. The IR spectrum of 6 shows a terminal pym mode at 1585cm-1 along with a ν(S-O) vibration at 1107cm-1, a ν(Ru-S) band at 421cm-1, and ν(Ru-Cl) vibrations at 339 and 324cm-1.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A library search in the Cambridge data file has revealed no Ru complexes containing both a sulfoxide and a monodentate pyrazine ligand. The two structures are also the first examples of Ru(III) compounds containing a monodentate pyrazine ligand. Three structures containing the pyrazine ligand bridging two Ru(III) atoms were found. These are the symmetric dimers Na[(DMSO)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Ru(μ-pz)RuCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(DMSO)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>DMSO  and (TMSO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H[(TMSO)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Ru(μ-pz)RuCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(TMSO)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COCH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (where TMSO<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>tetramethylenesulfoxide) , and the unsymmetrical NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>[(DMSO)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Ru(μ-pz)RuCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(S–DMSO)(O–DMSO)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH dimer . It seems that pyrazine usually function as a bridging ligand and it is more difficult to prepare complexes containing monodentate pyrazine ligands. In the preparation of these types of complexes, the potential bridging ligand was added in a large excess, in order to reduce the formation of pyrazine-bridged oligomeric species. The same is true for the bipyridine and pyrimidine complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A library search in the Cambridge data file has revealed no Ru complexes containing both a sulfoxide and a monodentate pyrazine ligand. The two structures are also the first examples of Ru(III) compounds containing a monodentate pyrazine ligand. Three structures containing the pyrazine ligand bridging two Ru(III) atoms were found. These are the symmetric dimers Na[(DMSO)Cl4Ru(μ-pz)RuCl4(DMSO)]⋅H2O⋅DMSO  and (TMSO)2H[(TMSO)Cl4Ru(μ-pz)RuCl4(TMSO)]⋅CH3COCH3 (where TMSO=tetramethylenesulfoxide) , and the unsymmetrical NH4[(DMSO)Cl4Ru(μ-pz)RuCl3(S-DMSO)(O-DMSO)]⋅CH3OH dimer . It seems that pyrazine usually function as a bridging ligand and it is more difficult to prepare complexes containing monodentate pyrazine ligands. In the preparation of these types of complexes, the potential bridging ligand was added in a large excess, in order to reduce the formation of pyrazine-bridged oligomeric species. The same is true for the bipyridine and pyrimidine complexes.

<ce:para view="all">The use of cations like <mml:math altimg="si16.gif" overflow="scroll">

</mml:math> or NR<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> which do not form H-bonds or other strong electrostatic attractions like alkali metals should prevent the formation of infinite chains or other materials with extended structures. In the few published structures containing Na cations with a tetrahedral environment, small oligomers are formed . In the case of crystal <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations have an octahedral environment and it can form bridges between the Ru(III) complexed anions to form a ID extended structure. It might be interesting to replace the Na atom by a larger metal like Ba, which could accept a larger environment, for example, a coordination number of 8 and form multidimensional (2D or 3D) materials. The formation of such species is an area of current interest in supramolecular chemistry. The study of multidimensional compounds is important in material science, especially for paramagnetic species.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The use of cations like     PPh   4     +     or NR4 + which do not form H-bonds or other strong electrostatic attractions like alkali metals should prevent the formation of infinite chains or other materials with extended structures. In the few published structures containing Na cations with a tetrahedral environment, small oligomers are formed . In the case of crystal 3, the Na+ cations have an octahedral environment and it can form bridges between the Ru(III) complexed anions to form a ID extended structure. It might be interesting to replace the Na atom by a larger metal like Ba, which could accept a larger environment, for example, a coordination number of 8 and form multidimensional (2D or 3D) materials. The formation of such species is an area of current interest in supramolecular chemistry. The study of multidimensional compounds is important in material science, especially for paramagnetic species.

</ce:display>The orange compound was crystallized in a mixture of acetone and diethylether and the crystals were studied by X-ray diffraction methods. The results have shown that the compound crystallized with a molecule of solvent (DMSO). The reported compound , which was not studied by crystallographic methods, contained 1.5 molecule of DMSO and 0.5 molecule of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, although it was crystallized from the same solvents.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

[(DMSO)2H]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4], [Na]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4], and [NBu4]trans-[RuCl4(DMSO)2] (Bu= n-butyl) were synthesized according to the literature methods .

 [PPh  4  ]trans-[Ru(DMSO)  2  Cl  4  ] (  1  ). Tetraphenylphosphonium chloride (0.34g, 0.92mmol) dissolved in 6mL of H2O was added to a solution of [(DMSO)2H]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4] (0.34g, 0.61mmol) dissolved in 3mL of H2O, while stirring. A yellow precipitate formed within minutes. The precipitate was collected by filtration, washed with diethylether and vacuum dried. Yield: 89%. IR (cm-1): 1107s ν(DMSO-S), 416w ν(Ru-S), 339, 319s ν(Ru-Cl). 1H NMR (CD3CN/ppm): -13.0 (DMSO-S), 7.95, 7.74 (phenyl protons).

 [PPh  4  ]trans-[Ru(DMSO)(pz)Cl  4  ] (  2  ). [PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4] (1) (0.30g, 0.40mmol) was dissolved in a mixture of 7mL acetone and 4mL acetonitrile, while 0.16g of pyrazine (pyz) (2.0mmol) was dissolved in 1mL of acetone. The ruthenium solution was added slowly to the pyrazine solution to form a clear orange mixture. After several hours the product precipitated as orange crystals. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with cold diethylether and vacuum dried. Yield: 73%. Alternatively, complex 2 can be synthesized from complex 3 by the addition of [PPh4]Br or [PPh4]Cl in aqueous solution. IR (cm-1): 1588 (pz), 1108s (DMSO-S), 420m ν(Ru-S), 342, 328s ν(Ru-Cl). 1H NMR (CD3CN/ppm): -12.6 (br, DMSO-S), -5.6 (vbr, pz H2,6), -1.6 (br, pz H3,5), 7.95, 7.74 (phenyl protons). Anal. Calc. for C30H30Cl4N2OPSRu: C, 48.6; H, 4.05; N 3.78. Found: C, 48.4; H, 3.84; N, 3.87%.

 [Na]trans-[Ru(DMSO)(pz)Cl  4  ] ⋅ DMSO (  3  ). The synthesis of this compound was similar to that reported  with some changes. Pyrazine (80.2mg, 1.00mmol) dissolved in 5mL of acetone was added to a solution of 82.5mg (0.198mmol) of [Na]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4] dissolved in 2mL of DMSO. The resulting mixture was filtered and the filtrate was stirred at room temperature for 1.5h. A 50/50 acetone/diethylether solution (5.0mL) was added to the reaction mixture followed by an additional 5.0mL of diethylether. The mixture was then placed at 4° C. Orange crystals appeared within 48h. The mother liquor was decanted and the crystals washed with diethylether. Yield: 67%. 1H NMR (D2O/ppm): -13.9 (br), (DMSO-S), -7.5 (vbr, H3,5 pyz), -2.1 (br, H2,6 pyz). This compound was reported, but the solvate molecules appear different .

 [NBu  4  ]trans-[RuCl  4  (DMSO)(bpy)] (bpy  =  4,4'-bipyridine) (  4  ). 0.63g of [NBu4]trans-[RuCl4(DMSO)2] (0.98mmol) was dissolved in 15mL of acetone and 0.60g of 4,4-bipyridine (3.8mmol) was dissolved in 4mL of acetone. The ruthenium solution was added to the 4,4-bipyridine solution to form a clear orange solution. After several hours of stirring, the product was precipitated after the addition of 10mL of cold diethylether. The yellow precipitate was collected by filtration, washed with cold diethylether and vacuum dried. Yield: 86% (0.60g). IR (cm-1): 1595, 1612w (bpy), 1109s (DMSO-S), 422m ν(Ru-S), 349, 325s ν(Ru-Cl). 1H NMR (acetone/ppm): -12.2 (br, DMSO-S), 7.5 (br, bpy     H     2   '   ,   6   '      ), 6.0 (br, bpy     H     3   '   ,   5   '      ), -1.2 (br, bpy H3,5), -6.0 (vbr, bpy H2,6).

 [PPh  4  ]trans-[RuCl  4  (DMSO)(bpy)] (  5  ). 0.50g of [PPh4]trans-[RuCl4(DMSO)2] (0.68mmol) was dissolved in 15mL of CH2Cl2 and 0.40g of 4,4-bipyridine (2.6mmol) was dissolved in 6mL of CH2Cl2. The ruthenium solution was added to the 4,4-bipyridine solution to form a clear orange solution. After several hours of stirring, the product was precipitated after the addition of 10mL of cold diethylether. The yellow precipitate was collected by filtration, washed with cold diethylether, and vacuum dried. Yield: 82% (0.45g). IR (cm-1): 1595, 1612w (bpy), 1107s (DMSO-S), 422m ν(Ru-S), 331s,br ν(Ru-Cl). 1H NMR (CDCl3/ppm): -12.8 (br, DMSO-S), 7.5 (br, bpy     H     2   '   ,   6   '      ), 5.5 (br, bpy     H     3   '   ,   5   '      ), -1.7 (br, bpy H3,5), 8.06 (br, phenyl protons). Anal. Calc. for C36H34Cl4N2OPSRu: C, 52.9; H, 4.17; N 3.43. Found: C, 52.6; H, 3.94; N, 3.23%.

 [PPh  4  ]trans-[RuCl  4  (DMSO)(pym)] (pym  =  pyrimidine) (  6  ). 0.20g of [PPh4]trans-[RuCl4(DMSO)2] (0.27mmol) was dissolved in 5mL of CH2Cl2 and 0.15g of pyrimidine (0.98mmol) was dissolved in 1mL of acetone. The ruthenium solution was added to the pyrimidine solution to form a clear orange solution. After several hours of stirring, the product was precipitated with the addition of 10mL of diethylether. The yellow precipitate was collected by filtration, washed with diethylether, and vacuum dried. Yield: 67% (0.133g). IR (cm-1): 1585, 1560 (pym), 1107s (DMSO-S), 421m ν(Ru-S), 339, 324sh ν(Ru-Cl). 1H NMR (CD3CN/ppm): -13.0 (br, DMSO-S), 6.34 (pym H4), -0.58 (br, pym H5), -1.7 (vbr, pym H6), -6.5 (vbr, pym H2), 7.96, 7.78 (br, phenyl protons); (CDCl3/ppm): -12.7 (br, DMSO-S), 6.32 (br, bpy H4), -0.52 (br, H5), 8.16 (br, phenyl protons). Anal. Calc. for C30H30Cl4N2OPSRu: C, 48.6; H, 4.05; N 3.78. Found: C, 48.4; H, 3.78; N, 3.77%.

[Na][Ru(DMSO)(pyrazine)Cl4]⋅DMSO (3)

This compound was synthesized from the reaction of [Na][Ru(DMSO)2Cl4] with pyrazine in acetone and DMSO similar to the procedure already reported.   [ Na ] [ Ru ( DMSO   )   2     Cl   4   ] + pz   →   DMSO   acetone   [ Na ] [ Ru ( DMSO ) ( pz )   Cl   4   ] ⋅ DMSO   The orange compound was crystallized in a mixture of acetone and diethylether and the crystals were studied by X-ray diffraction methods. The results have shown that the compound crystallized with a molecule of solvent (DMSO). The reported compound , which was not studied by crystallographic methods, contained 1.5 molecule of DMSO and 0.5 molecule of H2O, although it was crystallized from the same solvents.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was recrystallized from acetone/diethylether and the crystals were studied by crystallographic methods. The results have shown that the orange crystals consist of discrete complexed anions, [Ru(DMSO)(pz)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>) and [PPh<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations. The complexed anion is the <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> isomer and the coordination around the Ru(III) center is octahedral. The bond distances and angles are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>. The <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic> angles around the metal vary between 87.73(7)° and 92.66(3)°, while the <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> angles are between 177.32(3)° and 179.07(7)°. The Ru–Cl bond distances range from 2.3425(9) to 2.3589(10)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, the Ru–S bond is 2.2941(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the Ru–N distance is 2.118(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. These values are in agreement with published values found in a few related structures .</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The environment around the Na atoms was closely examined. There are six atoms in its close environment. The distances and angles are shown in . The geometry is a distorted octahedron. Three of the close contacts are shown in . The Na–O1 (from bonded DMSO) and Na–O2 (unbonded DMSO) distances are 2.303(2) and 2.324(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The Na–Cl4 distance is 2.9222(12) Å´. There are three other short contacts with the following: N4′ (2.519(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), Cl1′ (2.7760(13)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), and Cl4′ (2.8404(13)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The chloro ligand Cl4 forms a bridge between two Na atoms, while Cl1 forms a bridge between a Na and a Ru atom. The two other Cl ligands are not involved with the Na atoms. The DMSO ligand forms a bridge between a Ru (through its S atom) atom and a Na (through its O) atom, while the S atom of the second DMSO molecule is free, but its O atom is in the close environment of the Na atom. There are important distortions from the octahedral structure around the Na atom. The <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic> angles vary between 72.25(3)° (Cl′–Na–Cl4′) and 106.54(7)° (O2–Na–Cl4), while the <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> angles are between 154.51(7)° and 175.65(8)°.</ce:para><ce:section-title>[NBu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-[RuCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(DMSO)(bpy)] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) and [PPh<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-[RuCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(DMSO)(bpy)] (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">[PPh<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-[Ru(DMSO)(bpy)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>) (bpy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-bipyridine) was prepared from [PPh<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-[Ru(DMSO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] in methylene chloride as shown in the following equation:<ce:display>
<ce:formula>

</ce:display>The NMR spectrum of compound <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> showed, along with signals for the tetraphenyl phosphonium cation, several peaks for the protons of the coordinated ligands. The signal at −12.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is assigned to the coordinated DMSO while the peak at −1.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is assigned to the protons (H<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> and H<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>) on the coordinated pyridine ring but furthest from the paramagnetic ruthenium(III) center. The protons closest to the ruthenium center (H<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> and H<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>, ) are not observed due to a line-width that is too broad for the peak to be seen. The protons on the second pyridine ring are observed at 5.5 (<mml:math altimg="si11.gif" overflow="scroll">

cln_elements.clean_text:
Compound 2 was recrystallized from acetone/diethylether and the crystals were studied by crystallographic methods. The results have shown that the orange crystals consist of discrete complexed anions, [Ru(DMSO)(pz)Cl4]- ( ) and [PPh4]+ cations. The complexed anion is the trans isomer and the coordination around the Ru(III) center is octahedral. The bond distances and angles are shown in  . The cis angles around the metal vary between 87.73(7)° and 92.66(3)°, while the trans angles are between 177.32(3)° and 179.07(7)°. The Ru-Cl bond distances range from 2.3425(9) to 2.3589(10)Å, the Ru-S bond is 2.2941(9)Å and the Ru-N distance is 2.118(2)Å. These values are in agreement with published values found in a few related structures .

The environment around the Na atoms was closely examined. There are six atoms in its close environment. The distances and angles are shown in . The geometry is a distorted octahedron. Three of the close contacts are shown in . The Na-O1 (from bonded DMSO) and Na-O2 (unbonded DMSO) distances are 2.303(2) and 2.324(2)Å, respectively. The Na-Cl4 distance is 2.9222(12) Å´. There are three other short contacts with the following: N4' (2.519(2)Å), Cl1' (2.7760(13)Å), and Cl4' (2.8404(13)Å). The chloro ligand Cl4 forms a bridge between two Na atoms, while Cl1 forms a bridge between a Na and a Ru atom. The two other Cl ligands are not involved with the Na atoms. The DMSO ligand forms a bridge between a Ru (through its S atom) atom and a Na (through its O) atom, while the S atom of the second DMSO molecule is free, but its O atom is in the close environment of the Na atom. There are important distortions from the octahedral structure around the Na atom. The cis angles vary between 72.25(3)° (Cl'-Na-Cl4') and 106.54(7)° (O2-Na-Cl4), while the trans angles are between 154.51(7)° and 175.65(8)°.

[NBu4]trans-[RuCl4(DMSO)(bpy)] (4) and [PPh4]trans-[RuCl4(DMSO)(bpy)] (5)

[PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)(bpy)Cl4] (5) (bpy=4,4'-bipyridine) was prepared from [PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4] in methylene chloride as shown in the following equation:   [   PPh   4   ] trans - [ Ru ( DMSO   )   2     Cl   4   ] + 4 ,   4   '   -bpy   →   methylene chloride   [   PPh   4   ] [ Ru ( DMSO ) ( bpy )   Cl   4   ]   The NMR spectrum of compound 5 showed, along with signals for the tetraphenyl phosphonium cation, several peaks for the protons of the coordinated ligands. The signal at -12.8ppm is assigned to the coordinated DMSO while the peak at -1.7ppm is assigned to the protons (H3 and H5) on the coordinated pyridine ring but furthest from the paramagnetic ruthenium(III) center. The protons closest to the ruthenium center (H2 and H6, ) are not observed due to a line-width that is too broad for the peak to be seen. The protons on the second pyridine ring are observed at 5.5 (    H     3   '       and     H     5   '      ) and 7.5ppm (    H     2   '       and     H     6   '      ) for the two pairs closer and further from the ruthenium atom, respectively. The IR spectrum of 5 shows a terminal bpy mode at 1595cm-1 along with a ν(S-O) vibration at 1107cm-1, a ν(Ru-S) band at 422cm-1, and a ν(Ru-Cl) vibration at 331cm-1.

</ce:display>The NMR spectrum of compound <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> in acetonitrile solution showed, along with signals for the tetraphenylphosphonium cation, five peaks for the protons of the coordinated ligands. The signal at −13.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is assigned to the coordinated DMSO as expected. There are four peaks seen for the pyrimidine ligand as each proton is unique in this case due to the loss of symmetry in the ligand once it has coordinated. The peak at 6.34<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm has the narrowest line-width and is therefore assigned to the proton furthest from the paramagnetic center, H<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
. The peak at −0.58<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is assigned to the H<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup> proton similar to complex <ce:bold>3.</ce:bold> Two very broad peaks are observed at −1.7 and −6.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm and are assigned to H<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> and H<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, respectively, those closest to the paramagnetic ruthenium center. In chloroform solution the peaks were observed at 6.32, −0.52, and −12.7 for the H<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>, H<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>, and DMSO protons, respectively. The H<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> and H<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> protons were too broad to be seen. The IR spectrum of <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> shows a terminal pym mode at 1585<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> along with a <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(S–O) vibration at 1107<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, a <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(Ru–S) band at 421<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(Ru–Cl) vibrations at 339 and 324<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
[PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)(pym)Cl4] (6)

[PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)(pym)Cl4] (6) was prepared from [PPh4]trans-[Ru(DMSO)2Cl4] in methylene chloride as shown in the following equation:   [   PPh   4   ] trans - [ Ru ( DMSO   )   2     Cl   4   ] + pyrimidine   →   methylene chloride   [   PPh   4   ] [ Ru ( DMSO ) ( pym )   Cl   4   ]   The NMR spectrum of compound 6 in acetonitrile solution showed, along with signals for the tetraphenylphosphonium cation, five peaks for the protons of the coordinated ligands. The signal at -13.0ppm is assigned to the coordinated DMSO as expected. There are four peaks seen for the pyrimidine ligand as each proton is unique in this case due to the loss of symmetry in the ligand once it has coordinated. The peak at 6.34ppm has the narrowest line-width and is therefore assigned to the proton furthest from the paramagnetic center, H4 . The peak at -0.58ppm is assigned to the H5 proton similar to complex 3. Two very broad peaks are observed at -1.7 and -6.5ppm and are assigned to H6 and H2, respectively, those closest to the paramagnetic ruthenium center. In chloroform solution the peaks were observed at 6.32, -0.52, and -12.7 for the H4, H5, and DMSO protons, respectively. The H2 and H6 protons were too broad to be seen. The IR spectrum of 6 shows a terminal pym mode at 1585cm-1 along with a ν(S-O) vibration at 1107cm-1, a ν(Ru-S) band at 421cm-1, and ν(Ru-Cl) vibrations at 339 and 324cm-1.

spectrum.condition: NMR spectrum in acetonitrile and chloroform solution
